title: HEADS-ED
description: Screens for pediatric mental health needs in the emergency department. Evaluates 7 domains: Home, Education/employment, Activities/peers, Drugs/alcohol, Suicidality, Emotions/behaviors, and Discharge resources.

ranges.interpretation: Consider community resources and routine follow-up. No immediate psychiatric consultation needed unless other concerning factors present.
Referral for specialized mental health assessment is recommended. Consider psychiatric consultation and appropriate level of care based on clinical presentation.

special_rules: If Suicidality score = 2, immediate psychiatric consultation is recommended regardless of total score
Total score â‰¥8 OR Suicidality = 2 triggers recommendation for specialized mental health assessment

references: Cappelli M, Gray C, Zemek R, Cloutier P, Kennedy A, Glennie E, et al. The HEADS-ED: a rapid mental health screening tool for pediatric patients in the emergency department. Pediatrics. 2012 Aug;130(2):e321-7. doi: 10.1542/peds.2011-3798.

Cappelli M, Zemek R, Polihronis C, Thibedeau NR, Kennedy A, Gray C, et al. The HEADS-ED: Evaluating the Clinical Use of a Brief, Action-Oriented, Pediatric Mental Health Screening Tool. Pediatr Emerg Care. 2017 May;33(5):316-321. doi: 10.1097/PEC.0000000000000803.
formula: Total Score = Home + Education + Activities + Drugs + Suicidality + Emotions + Discharge (Range: 0-14)
notes: Designed for pediatric patients presenting to the emergency department with mental health concerns
Each domain scored 0-2 points: 0 = No action needed, 1 = Needs non-urgent action, 2 = Immediate action required
Suicidality score of 2 always warrants immediate psychiatric consultation
Higher scores correlate with increased likelihood of admission and psychiatric consultation
